title: uk multicultural map different religions statistics
story: The colour-coded graphic was created by coder Ben Flanagan - and each tiny dot represents a single religious person.It shows the scope of religions across several huge cities in Britain - and reveals that South London is almost entirely dominated by Christians.On the maps, green dots are for Buddhists, yellow dots are for Jews, orange dots are for Sikhs, purple dots are for Hindus, turquoise dots are for Muslims, and blue dots are Christians.Red dots mean people of other listed religions.The map of London is mostly blue, with small - but densely populated - enclaves of Hindus and Sikhs in the West, and Jews and Muslims in the North.Census figures reveal that the population of Harrow is 25 per cent Hindu.Tower Hamlets has the highest population of Muslims, and is visible on the map as a small concentration of turquoise dots near Bow.Blank areas are places where either no people live, or a high concentration of atheists.West Yorkshire shows high concentrations of Muslims in Bradford and Dewsbury, with the western half of Leicester almost entirely made up of Hindus and Sikhs.The Tyne and Wear is heavily Christian, with a small smattering of Jews near Gateshead.

title: brexit trading superpower small business liam fox
story: They want to buy British products, use British services, learn English. They trust our laws and our financial services, they admire our Armed Forces and they envy our universities.Actually, that’s not quite true: everywhere I go in the world, except right here in the UK.There are some who can’t or won’t see the natural advantages we have and the opportunities that exist for us. I get frustrated when some people purposefully choose to ignore good news such as last week when China opened up their market to UK dairy products.Britain can and should be confident and the world needs a confident Britain.A confident Britain can bang the drum for free trade across the world, as more and more countries look to pull up the drawbridge and turn away from the huge benefits that we have seen in poverty alleviation.A confident Britain can work with African countries to tackle extremism and instability which threatens millions of people across the world, including right here in the UK, as the Prime Minister promised to do this week.A confident Britain with an independent seat at the World Trade Organisation can be a leading voice for free trade and prosperity.A confident Britain is good for the world, and it’s good for us at home too. Why?Because free trade means we can sell more world-class British goods and services across the globe. That means safeguarding and creating jobs as well generating revenues for the Treasury to spend on our vital public services.That’s why I launched the Export Strategy last month: to turn the UK into a 21st Century exporting superpower.We need to work together to ­create a more confident Britain that can export to the world.To do that, we need to support business the length and breadth of the whole UK.Over 99 per cent of our businesses are small or medium-sized, and 96 per cent are micro-sized, employing fewer than nine people.That means many thousands of Sun on Sunday readers either own one or work for one.You are the lifeblood of our economy — it’s your entrepreneurship, risk-taking and innovation that drives the entire economy.It’s your wealth creation that provides the income we all depend on for our public services, from funding our NHS to paying our brave Armed Forces.It also means that you might not be exporting — yet — because more than 90 per cent of companies aren’t currently seizing the opportunities of exporting.That’s where we can help.Government doesn’t manufacture products and doesn’t provide services for exporting.But we can help create the right conditions by intervening where only government can.We have created a network of Her Majesty’s Trade Commissioners to lead the Government’s trade and investment promotion and policy in high-growth regions across the world.And I as International Trade Secretary can step in and speak to foreign ministers about overcoming a trade barrier — as I did last week, when I signed a deal in Beijing to enable the UK to export seed potatoes to China or help a UK company close a deal in an overseas market or seal a partnership with a foreign company.And to support British businesses — whether they produce farm products, or manufacture playgrounds, or provide legal services — we are also creating a network of Export Champions, people who run businesses that successfully export, to guide their peers and share their expertise.As I’ve often said before, in the next ten to 15 years, around 90 per cent of global economic growth is expected to be outside the EU.I truly believe that Brexit is an ­opportunity.The positive response and engagement we’ve seen from the EU negotiators to the Chequers proposals makes me believe that a good deal is now more likely.At Chequers the Government agreed its proposal for an economic partnership with the EU after the UK leaves on March 29, 2019.It confirmed that the UK will leave the Single Market and the Customs Union and will seize new opportunities from trading with the rest of the world.That’s why the Prime Minister visited Africa, one of the fastest-growing regions in the world, this week.It’s why I visited China last week, and am visiting India later in the autumn, to ensure Britain can make the most of their breakneck growth.Booming countries across the globe are confident in Britain.They’re confident in our crucial role in supporting world prosperity, world security and world growth.If they have faith in us, we need to have more faith. Because a more confident Britain is a better Britain for the world.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Brexit-backing Tory MPs are working on the benefits of a Canada-style deal and a no-deal scenario with a team of policy experts.It is set to be published just ahead of the Tories annual rally taking place in Birmingham later this month. It has been claimed around 100 MPs could back the alternative proposal.It comes as Eurosceptic MPs including former party leader Iain Duncan Smith and Cabinet Minister Priti Patel back the Stand Up 4 Brexit campaign.Ex-Minister Steve Baker last night said: “The Prime Minister should ‘chuck Chequers’ and stand up for Brexit based on advanced free trade agreement with the EU, an agreement of the kind the EU has offered in principle.”He has released a new video last night urging Mrs May to change her Brexit stance.Theresa May unveiled the Chequers blueprint in July which led to the resignations of her Brexit Secretary David Davis and Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson.Mr Johnson said Britain was heading “for the status of a colony” under the plan.Davis said he didn’t “believe” in the agreement reached by the Cabinet.Mr Baker last night said: “I expect our detailed proposals to be available in time for Conservative conference.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: primary school kids phonics
story: A thousand teachers will get help from a team of experts touring the country to boost reading and writing skills.Education Secretary Damian Hinds today reveals a phonics roadshow will tour the country to aid staff.Teachers across 500 schools in England will try and drive pupils up the international literacy league tables.The latest figures show England’s nine and ten-year-old’s are ranked joint eighth out of 50 countries.More than 150,000 pupils aged six are on track to be better readers than in 2012.The phonics method allows children to read and write by sounding out and blending letters.Mr Hinds will go on a fact-finding mission to Ireland which currently stands as the highest European country in the Progress in International Reading Literacy Study table.Mr Hinds last night said: “I know that first and foremost we want our kids to settle in, make new friends and be happy.“But parents also want to know that their children will be learning from the best teachers using the best teaching techniques as they develop their skills in reading and writing. As the summer holidays come to an end, more than four-and-a-half million children are preparing to go back to primary school this week.After a hectic few days of shopping for new shoes and uniforms, sewing on nametags and kitting out pencil cases, parents and families up and down the country will be feeling a mixture of relief, pride and hope for the future - and sometimes anxiety as well - as they wave off their children at the school gates.Particularly for those parents whose kids are just starting at primary school, I know this is both an exciting and nerve-wracking time.As a parent, I know that first and foremost we want our kids to settle in, make new friends and be happy.But parents also want to know that their children will be learning from the best teachers using the best teaching techniques as they develop their skills in reading and writing.That’s why today I’m announcing more help for our brilliant teachers to teach reading through the proven phonics methods – where children learn to read by sounding out and blending the letters.Championed by this government, phonics has already helped our children become better readers. 154,000 more six year olds are now on track to be fluent readers than in 2012 and in the latest PIRLS results – an international study of reading at primary school – England achieved its highest ever score.Our phonics blitz will continue and we’re sending experts all over the country to give advice on phonics teaching to 500 schools and almost 1,000 teachers.As the schools year starts, I want all parents to know that I want all children to get the very best education from day one and throughout their school years - helping to give them a happy childhood while preparing them for life in the modern world.“That’s why today I’m announcing more help for our brilliant teachers to teach reading through the proven phonics methods – where children learn to read by sounding out and blending the letters.“Championed by this government, phonics has already helped our children become better readers.“Our phonics blitz will continue and we’re sending experts all over the country to give advice on phonics teaching to 500 schools and almost 1,000 teachers.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says theresa may brexit referendum
story: The demands for a “people’s vote” on a final Brexit deal are increasingly shrill.These celebrity millionaire luvvies are either wilfully ignorant or they really just don’t get it, do they?Do they have any idea of the anger that would be unleashed if they stopped Brexit? They want our politicians to get on with it.Mrs May has also claimed that she is going to start focusing on her domestic agenda. title: uk smallest baby 12 oz can of coke
story: Little Theo Taylor survived incredible odds after being born at just 26 weeks and five days by emergency C-section.He stopped growing in mum, Katie Rhodes womb and docs even offered her an abortion the day before he was born.But plucky Theo is now six months old and at home with mum Katie, 24, and Jay, 27.He is thought to be the smallest newborn to survive in the UK since Aaliyah Hart, now 15, was born at 12oz in 2003.Katie said: “Before he was born, it was really hard hearing all the time that he wasn’t going to make it, and even when he was born that we might not get to take him home.“But we got through it by saying, ‘no, he’s made it this far, let’s just support him’.“We were so positive and kept saying that we would fight for him.”Dad Jay added: “I had never ever seen a baby that small – I didn’t know babies could be that small.“I kept saying to Katie that everything would be ok and he would be fine.“But it wasn’t until I saw him that I realised how serious things were. I think that was the most scared I have ever been.”A bombshell 19-week scan revealed Theo had stopped growing.Jay, a delivery driver, said: “They were all really good and helpful, but right up until the day before he was born, we were offered an abortion.”After he was born medics warned he was so small he might not survive long enough to go home.Jay said: “He was smaller than my hand and much smaller than they even thought he would be.“The doctor said he was about the weight of a can of Coke, but even when I picked up a can, it felt heavier than Theo.He added: “He is proving everyone wrong. The doctors that first looked after him came in over the weeks to see him and could not believe how well he was doing.”Theo still needs oxygen but doctors say he has avoided other complications.His family is raising money for Tiny Lives, a charity that helps care for premature babies and their families.

title: kanye west hints he may run for president in 2024 and says it 100 could happen
story: The 41-year-old musician, who has been criticised for supporting sitting president Donald Trump, joked he would run for the Birthday Party.West first expressed his desire to get into the White House at the MTV Video Music Awards back in 2015.Asked if hes still considering launching an election bid, he told Power 92: Yes. It 100 percent could happen. 2024.If I decide to do it, it will be done. I’m not gonna try.He also said being an entrepreneur has prepared him for the hot seat, adding: You should not be president unless youve ran a multi-billion dollar business.West, who has been married to Kim Kardashian since 2014, also talked about reducing tension between the police and black community.The world was first alerted to his lofty ambitions in 2015 when he was accepting a lifetime achievement award at the VMAs in Los Angeles, California.He told the crowd: As you probably could’ve guessed by this moment, I have decided, in 2020, to run for president.Although admitting he did not know much about politics, he reckoned he was qualified because of his view on humanity, on people and the truth.He also announced earlier in the speech that he had smoked a joint before heading onto the stage.West said: You might be thinking right now, I wonder did he smoke something before he came out here?And the answer is yes, I rolled up a little something, I knocked the edge off.But in December 2016, Kanye met the then President-elect Donald Trump and followed that up with a simple tweet stating #2024.Kanye has not kept his admiration for Trump a secret and in April, he angered his fans and even wife Kim when he expressed his lovefor the US president.The outspoken rapper, who visited Trump Tower in 2016 following the billionaire’s sensational election victory, called the Republican my brother.Kayne claims he and the US President, 71, both have “dragon energy”, tweeting: “You don’t have to agree with Trump but the mob can’t make me not love him.Their unconventional bromance stretches back to September 2015 when Trump was already causing a stir in the Republican primaries – annihilating his opponents with savage putdowns.When asked about Kanye’s flippant announcement that he would run for President in 2020, the New York property tycoon said: “You know what, I’ll never say bad about him.“You know why? Because he loves Trump. He goes around saying, Trump is my all time hero. He says it to everybody. So Kanye West, I love him.

title: man nightclub pig delilah travellers
story: Thomas Murphy-Hankin, 26, was arrested after being found shouting and screaming in the street in Norwich with his porcine pal.He was charged with having a pig untethered and loose on a public highway, which is illegal.Murphy-Hankin, of no fixed address, admitted allowing an animal to stray on a highway on 8 August and not ensuring its welfare.He was fined £300 and was also banned from keeping pigs for two years, at Norwich magistratesMalcolm Plummer, representing Murphy-Hankin, said: He said he was given the pig by some travellers.“He felt sorry for it, so was looking after it.Im sure it was cute. He has no skills or knowledge in animal husbandry.He added that his client and the pig were parva sprayed during the incident, so it was more a case of “peppered pig than Peppa Pig”.Police spoke to Murphy-Hankin around 10am after reports that he had been shouting abuse at passers-by.When they arrived police found Murphy-Hankin sitting in a doorway with a bottle of alcohol and the pig between his legs with no restraint.Andrew Nickerson, prosecuting, said while the defendant, who also had a dog with him, was being arrested the pig was “wandering around” on the road and had to be sedated.Mr Nickerson said the pig was checked over by a vet and found to be very young, possibly only a few days old.He said the vet found the pig had “quite acute” sunburn, was quite malnourished and for the first 24 hours needed to be fed milk every hour.He was also accused of a public order offence and having a dog dangerously out of control in a public place.But there were no welfare concerns for two dogs found with Mr Murphy-Hankin, the court heard.

title: help to buy could be scrapped
story: The programme gives cheap loans to first-time buyers hoping to get on the housing ladder and is supposed to ensure they’re not put off by the cost of a deposit.But stats have shown that much of the money available has gone to wealthy house-hunters - and critics claim the scheme has driven up already sky-high property prices.Now ministers are planning to replace it with a new system after the current arrangement expires in 2021, according to the Sunday .The Government may introduce a temporary extension to avoid massive disruption for developers, the paper said.But the new regime would put more emphasis on helping out the lower-paid, rather than giving handouts to the middle classes.Official figures released earlier this year showed that the average household benefiting from Help to Buy earns £55,000.And some of those using the scheme are drawing salaries of as much as £100,000, the Government admitted.Critics have accused Help to Buy of helping to push up house prices, because it boosts demand for housing without doing anything to increase supply.Matt Kilcoyne from the Adam Smith Institute think-tank told The Sun: Help to Buy has been no help to the vast majority.“Scrapping the scheme is a good step toward a housing market that works for everyone. The well-off shouldnt get a hand out from government that pushes up the price of houses in already expensive markets.”He called for ministers to take more radical steps to reduce the cost of housing - such as relaxing planning laws and even scrapping the Green Belt.But developers today warned the Government that scrapping Help to Buy could prove devastating for the construction sector and housing market generally.David OLeary of the Home Builders Federation told the Sunday : As well as supporting hundreds of thousands of first-time buyers on to the housing ladder, Help to Buy has driven unprecedented growth in housing supply since 2013. Builders continue to invest in new land and labour to build more.Without the scheme in some form, the Governments ambition to deliver 300,000 new homes per year will be even tougher to achieve.A Government spokesman said: The vast majority of those using our Help to Buy equity loan scheme are first-time buyers, as we help a new generation of people own a home of their own.More than half of households using it earn less than £50,000, so we are also helping those on lower and middle incomes get on the property ladder.Shadow Housing Secretary John Healey called for a change to the status quo, saying: As it stands, the scheme is poorly targeted and poor value for taxpayers money. Help to Buy should be overhauled and tightly targeted on first-time buyers with ordinary incomes, as Labour has long-argued.

title: inuries cyclist pothole flung into air
story: Kevin Farrell needed surgery to repair his torn nose and lip and is now on a liquid diet after being flung through the air on the outskirts of York during a ride.The 53-year-old thinks the enormous pothole will kill the next person to fall foul of it.His front tyre exploded after going over the hole, and was unseated before his fellow four buddies ploughed into him.Dad-of-two Kevin, a self-employed electrical contractor from York, said: Weve seen potholes all summer long and we just dont see them getting repaired.Were all experienced, but if it was a child or someone less experienced, who knows what might have happened?The other four riders suffered injuries including a broken clavicle, cracked vertebrae and bleeding on the kidneys, as well as cuts and abrasions.Despite light being poor at the time of the smash, all the cyclists were using lights and wearing helmets, hi-vis gear and safety glasses.Kevin, who is hoping to seek legal action, said: There was a big lorry behind us, so it couldve been a lot worse.I think the helmet saved me and I think its time they were made compulsory.I just dont want somebody else to get hurt. It always takes something bad to happen before anything is done.The incident happened in Wigginton Road on the outskirts of York city centre at 8.30pm last Wednesday .Luckily, there was a North Yorkshire Police van nearby and the officers helped stop traffic and called ambulances, while the hospital was only five minutes away.City of York Council said it was not aware of the incident but pledged to investigate if supplied more information.A spokesman for City of York Council said: Were sorry to hear that a group of cyclists had an accident on Wigginton Road on Wednesday. We have not been made aware of an incident.Our inspectors check Wigginton Road on a regular basis.We would welcome further information so we can investigate if a repair is required to prevent a re-occurrence.As with any insurance claim this will be assessed by our insurers - we wish them a speedy recovery.

title: brits sizzle in 26c today as indian summer sweeps in and heat could last until november
story: Yesterday saw the start of meteorological autumn but you wouldn’t have known it from the sunshine.Thousands took to the nation’s beaches to soak up the sun, with Brits still seeking a tan despite the official end of the scorching summer of 2018.And the good weather is showing no signs of stopping with warmer than average temperatures set to continue into the next week.Met Office forecaster Steven Keates told The Sun: “This afternoon will see a west/east split today.“Western areas will be fairly cloudy with scattered drizzly showers and eventually heavy ran coming in to northern Scotland.“Eastern areas will see dry and fine weather with a good bit of sunshine with temperatures of up to 25C or 26C.“Tonight the rain coming into the north of Scotland will work its way down the country so that by tomorrow morning parts of northern England and wales will see some outbreaks of rain.“Southeast England will be dry and mostly clear with temperatures around the same as before.He added: “The rest of Monday will see some outbreaks of rain but nothing too heavy with the best of the weather remaining in the Southeast.“The bulk of Scotland and Northern Ireland will also enjoy a drier and brighter start to the week.“On Tuesday that weather front will fizzle out with thicker cloud moving across the East Midlands with most of the country remaining relatively warm.“Moving into next week the temperatures could rise even higher with the south experiencing the best of the weather with particularly warm days but punctuated by cool nights.“Our seasonal forecast also hints that the period from now till November will be warmer and dryer than normal.”The Autumn sizzle, hot on the heels of ­Britain’s heatwave Summer, will be caused by high pressure and a slight wind bringing temperatures from the continent.The South Coast is expected to get the best conditions with the possibility of the heat spreading northwards.

title: queen balmoral princess anne smiling
story: The Queen was pictured beaming in the back of a Bentley as she arrived at Crathie Kirk with her daughter Princess Anne.The 92-year-old monarch cut a stylish figure in a black coat teamed with a lime green hat as she waved to onlookers on the way to the chapel.Princess Anne wore a cream coat with blue flecks and a pale blue shawl wrapped around her shoulders.The 68-year-old Princess Royal topped off her ensemble with a white hat trimmed with a blue ribbon and a cream flower.Her husband Vice Admiral Sir Timothy Laurence sat up front with the chauffer seat teaming a tweed jacket with an orange tie.Prince Charles, who opted to drive himself to the service, and Camilla also have a home, Birkhall, on the Balmoral Estate and have been spending time with the QueenIt is not clear if the Duchess of Cornwall was among those attending church this morning.The Queen moved into Balmoral castle, in Aberdeenshire, at the beginning of August for the start of her summer break.Crathie Kirk lies next door and the Queen regularly attends during her annual Caledonian getaway.Yesterday she attended the Braemar Gathering – the biggest event in Scotlands Highland Games calendar.As patron of the Games, which are held just a short distance from her summer retreat, Her Majesty joined thousands of spectators to watch a festival of caber tossing and tugs of war.The event is held on the first Saturday in September at The Princess Royal and Duke of Fife Memorial Park in the Aberdeenshire town.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex were also visiting the Queen at Balmoral but were not pictured attending church as were the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge.

The horrific crime happened at 11:30 p.m. Wednesday in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens in Brooklyn, New York, officials said.The suspect, identified by police sources as El Salvadoran immigrant Julio Cesar Ayala, 18, had allegedly climbed onto the roof of the girl’s apartment building.He then somehow shoved aside the girl’s window air conditioner on the second floor and crawled inside through the opening, police sources said.He then allegedly raped the girl in her bed, officials said.But he dashed back out the window as she screamed to alert her mother, who rushed to her aid, the New York Post reports.The mum called cops but did not catch sight of the attacker, the sources said.By luck police were able to grab video-surveillance images of the suspect.On Saturday at 2:35 p.m., some 30 officers from the NYPD’s Emergency Service Unit and the 70th Precinct converged on ­Ayala at his hideaway in an under-construction three-story building at 930 Flatbush Ave.They pulled out the scrawny, hunched man, who was seen handcuffed and dressed in filthy black jeans and a red T-shirt.Ayala — who police sources said carried a federal Permanent Resident Card, also known as a “Green Card,” as his only identification — was led struggling into a police SUV.A high-level police source told The New York Post that investigators believe Ayala is a member of the violent MS-13 gang.Cheers and taunts rose from a crowd of dozens of spectators as Ayala was hauled out.Some applauded and took pictures on their phones.“They got him!” one man yelled.“He raped somebody, an 11-year-old girl,” another onlooker said.Ayala was charged Saturday night with sexually motivated burglary and first-degree rape.He has no previous criminal record, sources said.The crime shocked residents in the girl’s tidy neighbourhood of two- and three-story homes.“That makes me feel unsafe in my own home,” said Elizabeth Bardourilla, 42, a mental-health counsellor.“That child can’t help herself. For a grown man to do that. Sick. Very sick. This is sad. Just sad.”“That’s horrible,” added David Cadogan, 40, a paramedic.“I got a son and nieces. I don’t play with stuff like that. There’s past a point where you tolerate certain behaviours.“I know people want to wait on the law. But if anything happens to him between now and then, I honestly don’t care. He gets what he deserves.”A version of this story first appeared on the New York Post.

title: waitress sues her boss after he demanded that she wears a bra to work
story: Christina Schell, 25, said she was forced out of her job at Osoyoos Golf Club in British Columbia in Canada, for refusing to comply with what she claimed was a “sexist” dress code.Miss Schell had only been working at the golf club for three weeks before she was fired.She said she stopped wearing bras three years ago for comfort and health reasons – and it had never presented any problems before.After she started working at the Greenside Grill in the golf club in June this year, customers complained about her being braless – and so bosses brought in a new dress code.It stated that women “must wear either a tank top or bra under their uniform shirt.”Miss Schell refused to sign and said she was fired as a result. She’s now filed a human rights complaint.Speaking to the Osoyoos Times she said: “No male employee is required to wear an undershirt. So this is where it becomes a discriminatory issue for me…I don’t think it’s anybody else’s business what’s under my clothes.“As a female, that I can’t choose my undergarments in this day and age, it’s really, really tough.”She added: “Why do you get to dictate what’s underneath my clothes?“I’d love to know why my boobs offend somebody. They’re not hanging down by my waist. If they were, whose problem is it but mine? These things happen and these things aren’t right.”Miss Schell said she confronted the golf club’s manager, Doug Robb, and he allegedly told her the dress code was for her protection.She claimed he told her: “I know what happens in golf clubs when alcohol is involved.”Employment lawyer David Brown said dress codes that apply different rules for different genders could be viewed as discriminatory under the British Columbia Human Rights Code.He said: It’s an interesting question as to whether or not an employer can dictate the underwear that women can wear, but they don’t say anything about the underwear that men can wear, and does that create an adverse impact on the individual?”Mr Robb declined to comment, saying employee matters were confidential.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tony liberato forgione fish chip shop hoddersdon
story: Tony and Liberato Forgione, who both own shops in Hoddesdon, Herts, are among the top 20 entrants in the National Fish and Chip Awards 2019.Tony, 44, has run Captains Fish and Chips for 20 years and narrowly missed out on a top three position in the contest last year.He told the Express: It wasn’t just a flash in the pan. We’re back in the running this year and hope to do even better.Liberato, 47, only opened Sidney and Sons Fish and Chips in March just a mile away from his younger brother, and says its a great achievement to be amongst the top 20 after just five months.You could say it was an ‘Oh my cod’ situation, he added.While theres rivalry between the brothers as they both want to be good, Tony says: I’ve been here for 20 years so I know what my customers are having before they open their mouths.But Liberato believes his offerings of grilled sea bass and salmon could give him the competitive edge.Despite the competition, Tony says the real winner is the customer.He said: The person who really wins in the end is the customer. For Hoddesdon to have two fish and chip shops in the top 20 is brilliant.And it appears the two brothers are chips off the old block, as dad Sidney - now aged 81 - moved to England from Italy in 1957 and set up his first shop in East Finchley, North London, in 1963.And their brother Luigi runs Luigis Fish and Chips in Harlow, Essex, which was among the top 60 entrants in the UK-wide competition.The National Fish &amp Chip Awards carefully assesses the chippies on a number of factors.These range from considering sustainable sourcing policies, menu development and innovation to staff training policies and marketing activities.Those in the top 20 will compete in two further rounds of judging to make it to the nation number ones chippy, as the shops undergo a further phase of mystery diner judging inspections to whittle down further to the top 10 shortlist.The finalists will be scaled down to ten contenders in September and the winner of the Fish and Chip Shop of the Year Award will be announced at The National Fish &amp Chip Awards 31st anniversary ceremony in London on 24 January 2019.

title: almost third puppies sold online
story: NewsAlmost third of puppies sold online die or get ill before first birthday as owners seek 'instant gratification'An estimated 630,000 puppies among a dog population of nine million were ordered online and delivered directly to homesShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor19:48, 2 SEP 2018NewsBruno and Poppy with carer Emma Smith at a dog rehoming centre "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAlmost a third of puppies bought online die or fall ill within their first year, a charity has warned. Research found 18% of owners who bought their pet over the internet after finding an advert online said their dog had been sick before its first birthday, with the illness continuing throughout its life or until its death. A further 13% said their puppy had fallen ill in the first 12 months but went on to recover. The Kennel Club survey comes after the Government announced plans last month to ban the sale of puppies and kittens by pet shops and other third-party dealers.  The pledge was a victory for the Mirror’s Lucy’s law campaign, named after a Cavalier King Charles Spaniel rescued from a Welsh puppy farm five years ago. The Kennel Club warned that puppies were being put at risk by a culture of “instant gratification”.  Its poll of 2,176 dog owners found one in three people do less than two hours’ research when buying a puppy, while 12% of people - equating to roughly a million dogs - pay for their puppy before they have even seen it.

title: my parents virus wipe out
story: News'My parents are a virus I have to wipe out' says heroin addict who murdered his family for moneyKyle Navin had a monstrous plan to stop his family cutting him out of their willShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByGail Shortland07:00, 2 SEP 2018Updated08:28, 2 SEP 2018NewsKyle Navin killed his parents"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailKyle Navin had been drifting through life without a purpose for far too long. In high school he’d been a hockey star and, when he left, he joined his family’s rubbish collection business. He had a bright future ahead of him. But before long, drug addictions had left Kyle, 29, in debt and he was increasingly distracted at work. His parents were upset they couldn’t get through to him, but they had no idea Kyle was working on an idea that would turn his life around. In May 2015, Kyle sent a text message to his girlfriend Jennifer Valiante saying he had come up with the ‘perfect plan’ that would ‘solve every single problem and give us a wealthy, amazing life.’ It got her interest. It seemed Kyle had found a way to get himself out of the rut he was in. Kyle’s parents, Jeffrey and Jeanette, owned J &amp J Refuse, a rubbish collection business, in Easton, Connecticut. They’d given Kyle a job but knew he was a heroin addict. The couple were growing increasingly worried about their son.  They’d reached out to him about his drug use and offered to find him the help he desperately needed, but he’d refused. Jeffrey, usually a happy, positive man grew withdrawn. A friend later said that Jeffrey thought of nothing else but how they could help Kyle. A few years earlier, Jeffrey and Jeanette had helped their son buy a house, but he was falling behind with mortgage payments and bills. Finally, they decided it was time for some tough love. Jeffrey, 56, and Jeanette, 55, decided they were going to sell their company and stop financially supporting Kyle. Jeanette even told a friend they were ready to cut him out of their will, too. Somehow, Kyle found out. It motivated him to finally take control. It was then that he started to send his girlfriend text messages about his plan to fix everything and make them rich. He wrote about how he was going to ‘wipe out the virus and get money for life.’ On August 4, 2015, Jeanette and Jeffrey disappeared. Friends and family hoped they’d gone on an unannounced trip but their bank account was untouched and their pick-up truck was found abandoned in a car park. When questioned by police, Kyle claimed he and his mum had done a rubbish route together on the morning of August 4, and she’d been picked up by his dad afterwards.  It seemed like a plausible account and, at first, Kyle wasn’t a suspect. But he started to change his story, which aroused suspicion. Investigators looked into his phone records and discovered that Kyle’s mobile was in the same area as his parents’ phones on the day they vanished.  Two months later, their bodies were found in a wooded area close to a vacant house in nearby Weston. Workers had been clearing land and found their decomposed corpses in bags, buried under leaves. They’d been shot with a .40 calibre handgun. Police started to piece everything together – and Kyle was their prime suspect.  Murder supplies Investigators searched Kyle’s house. As well as drug paraphernalia, there was a blood stain that matched his dad’s DNA on a rug in the basement. There was also blood that matched his mum’s DNA in the boot of his truck. CCTV footage was found of Kyle and Jennifer at a local DIY store buying bleach, bin bags and drain unblocker – items police believe they used to try and cover-up the murders. They concluded that the ‘plan’ they’d been talking about for months was the murder of Jeanette and Jeffrey. They had been the ‘virus’ that Kyle talked about, and the way they were going to get wealthy was by inheriting their money before they could change their wills. Kyle and Jennifer, 31, were both arrested. Kyle was charged with murder and Jennifer was charged with conspiracy to commit murder and hindering prosecution. Investigators determined that Kyle had sat next to his mother in a garbage truck when she’d helped him out on his collection route. He’d pulled out a gun and shot her twice in the chest. His mobile phone records placed him at the scene. He then waited at home in the house his parents had bought him in Bridgeport, Connecticut, and a couple of hours later, he shot his father dead with the same gun.  Text messages Experts found text messages from Kyle to his dad on the day they were killed that suggested Jeffrey knew their lives were at risk, and he thought Kyle was going to set him up. ‘I’m not going home ‘till I know Mom is ok,’ Jeffrey wrote. ‘Did you hurt Mom?’ Kyle replied: ‘No absolutely not. Why would you think?’  ‘I go home and get framed for murder,’ Jeffrey replied. Kyle told him to stop being silly, and, although Jeffrey threatened to go to the police,  he must have gone to meet his son.  Kyle was held on a 2.5 million  bond and Jennifer’s was 2 million . At first, they both denied everything and pleaded not guilty. But the evidence was so convincing, they both changed their pleas. In April this year, the day before his trial was due to start, Kyle pleaded guilty to two counts of murder. He knew the damning text messages had sealed his fate and when prosecution indicated they would be used in the trial, he knew a jury would convict him.  When making his plea, the judge asked Kyle whether he agreed with the prosecutor’s version of how he killed his parents and he replied, ‘More or less’. At the sentencing, Kyle declined to make a statement publicly, saying he didn’t want to be a ‘show pony for the media.’ He was sentenced to serve 55 years for each of the murders and told they would run concurrently. He will not be eligible for early release. The judge called his actions ‘disgraceful and disgusting’. He pointed out that since 1986, there had only been 113 cases in the US of someone accused of killing their mother, adding that it was a ‘black-hearted crime’. ‘This idea of a killing by a child of his parents is exceedingly rare, it cuts against the fundamentals of our human condition, you don’t kill the people who gave life to you,’ he said. ‘One can only imagine the horror of Jeanette Navin when her son pulled a gun on her and shot her as she sat next to him.’

One family dressed as The Incredibles, while other people had disguised themselves as Dalmatians for a charity mixed netball tournament.  The event, in aid of former Exeter Chiefs rugby player Ian Stewart who has terminal cancer, was due to start at 8.30am but the mishap meant he teams didn't get in until 10.45am, Devon Live reports.  Exeter players and many families were among those left twiddling their thumbs outside West Exe School in the city in scenes described as shambolic by local residents who faced disruption as a result of the crowd. A spokeswoman for Sodexo, which manages events at the premises out of school hours, said: “The person who was supposed to turn up and open the gates is a part-time adhoc Sodexo employee.  Unfortunately he did sleep in this morning and when were alerted we got an out of hours member of staff to open up the venue. “We would like to apologise for any inconvenience.” The event has gone ahead and is being held in aid of retired rugby player Ian Stewart and his family. Event organiser Anita Palmer, chairman of West Exe Netball Club, said: “I was here at 8.10am and the employee should have been here to unlock the gates at 7.30am but I was told he overslept. “I was told at 10am he was 10 minutes away but no one came until 10.45am and it wasn’t him. “It has meant about 500 people and their cars have been on Hatherleigh Road this morning. Half of the Exeter Chief players are here. “We have had people travel from as far away as Wales and London. It’s been chaos and understandably the local residents have not been happy. “The girls at the netball club have been wonderful putting the event together so quickly, and it was all booked and paid for so to have this happen is awful.” Among those who are taking part in today’s event is the Bassett family who are donning The Incredibles fancy dress costumes. They said: “It has been an absolute shambles. All these people have come together for the charity event and have just been stood here.” The event, involving 34 teams - including rugby and football players - was scheduled to run from 10.20am to 5pm, and the fancy dress theme is Disney as the Stewart family are self-confessed ‘Disney nuts’. It has been organised by West Exe Netball Club which Ian’s daughter attends.

Margaret James, 92 – train station tea room waitress Beryl Walters in the 1945 tearjerker – has wed Rob Cave, 91. title: uks smallest baby born weighing
story: NewsUK's smallest baby born weighing same as can of Coke goes home with parents for first time at six months oldTiny Theo Taylor defied all odds to survive despite weighing just 350g when born premature at 26 weeks - after doctors offered mum Katie Rhodes a termination the day beforeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLaura ElvinEd McConnell17:47, 2 SEP 2018Updated19:02, 2 SEP 2018NewsBaby Theo was born weighing the same as a can of Coke "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTiny Theo Taylor weighed the same as a can of Coke when he was born. Now six months old and at home with his parents Katie Rhodes, 24, and Jay Taylor, 27, he is believed to be the smallest baby to survive in the UK.  Theo stopped growing in the womb and was so small doctors even offered Miss Rhodes a termination the day before he was born.   But the little fighter defied the odds to pull through despite weighing just 350g .   Theo was born early at 26 weeks and five days and Miss Rhodes, a support worker from Durham says he's a little fighter.  She added: Before he was born, it was really hard hearing all the time that he wasn't going to make it, and even when he was born that we might not get to take him home.   But we got through it by saying, 'no, he's made it this far, lets just support him'.   We were so positive and kept saying that we would fight for him.  Mr Taylor added: I had never ever seen a baby that small - I didn't know babies could be that small.  I kept saying to Katie that everything would be ok and he would be fine, but it wasn't until I saw him that I realised how serious things were.    I think that was the most scared I have ever been, but it was also a relief to see him.    Miss Rhodes' pregnancy was normal until the 19-week scan revealed Theo was smaller than expected.   Delivery driver Mr Taylor and Miss Rhodes discovered he'd stopped growing and were told to expect the worse and prepare for a demise at almost every scan or meeting.   The mum-to-be was admitted to hospital with pre-eclampsia and three days later doctors performed an emergency c-section when tests showed Theo had fluid around his heart.   They were all really good and helpful and said they would do anything they could to help him, but right up until the day before he was born, we were offered an abortion, said Mr Taylor.   Doctors estimated he would be 450g - still below the 500g 'ideal' - but when he was born on March 15 at Newcastle's Royal Victoria Infirmary Theo was only 350g.   The couple only got to touch his hand for a few seconds before he was put on a breathing machine using the smallest possible tube. Doctors warned that he was so small he might not survive long enough to come home.   But his proud parents got to hold him properly after two weeks, and he was moved to a lower dependency ward when he was seven weeks old and 3lb.    Mr Taylor said: He was smaller than my hand and much smaller than they even thought he would be, but doctors said he didn't have any of the usual complications premature babies have.  The doctor said he was about the weight of a can of Coke, but even when I picked up a can, it felt heavier than Theo.   On the day he was born one doctor said 'don't take for granted that you will be able to take him home'.  But he is proving everyone wrong.    The doctors that first looked after him came in over the weeks to see him and couldn't believe how well he was doing.   Theo, who was due on June 17, finally came home on July 7 weighing 7lb 4oz, after an operation to remove a hernia.  He is still on nasal oxygen at home but is gradually being brought off it. Doctors don't think he'll suffer any problems in the future. Miss Rhodes added: It's much easier with him home now than in hospital. It feels like he has been with us for much longer than six months. It's weird to think that he was the smallest baby ever as he is so much bigger than he was and is doing so well now.

story: NewsUK weather forecast: Brits sizzle in 26C heat but 'Indian Summer' may see temperatures surge to 30C before OctoberBeaches across the south-east were packed as temperatures soared to as high as 26C today - and we can expect the good weather to continueShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAdam Aspinall17:23, 2 SEP 2018Updated17:29, 2 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/weather-forecast-first-week-september-13181987,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrits basked in the last of the summer holiday sunshine today - but there is no need to pack away the BBQs just yet. Beaches across the south-east of England were packed as temperatures soared to as high as 26C  in London and the south-east. And we can expect the good weather to continue in most parts of the country this week with September forecast to be largely warm and sunny. British bookmakers are even claiming September 2018 has the potential of being the hottest ever. Leading bookmaker Coral has cut the odds on this month ending as the hottest September on record in the UK into 6-4  after a warm start to the month. The firm is odds-on at 10-11 for 30C or higher to be recorded at any point in September.    Coral’s John Hill said: “It has been a warm start to the month which has prompted a flurry of bets on this September ending as the hottest on record in the UK. “The betting suggests temperatures will reach 30C or higher at some point in September therefore the barbecues shouldn’t be put away for the year just yet.” But the forecast for the week ahead sees the nation split from East to West with the western half of Britain and the south enjoying the better weather.    MET office weather forecaster Steven Keats said: “There is going to be an East/West split throughout the week with the East enjoying the warmer temperatures while the West experiences more chilly conditions. “Overall though it is going to be a pretty typical September week for most with sunny days and the odd rainstorm here and there. “It is going to be pretty good-going in the south and east with temperatures peaking at around 26C  at points but in the north and West and Scotland there will be a chance of rain with the top temperature there being around 17C .” Tomorrow, heavy showers over Wales and north-east England but these will fizzle out in the west through the day, but may persist for eastern England into the evening. Elsewhere, there will be sunny spells, and it will remain rather warm in the south-east with gentle to moderate winds. On Sunday, incredible pictures showed a rare tornado-like funnel of wind which was spotted in the UK. Autumn heatwaves are often referred to as Indian summers, but what does the term actually mean?  The Met Office Meteorological Glossary, first published in 1916, defines an Indian summer as a warm, calm spell of weather occurring in autumn, especially in October and November. The exact origins of the phrase are uncertain and several writers have speculated it may originally have referred to a spell of warm, hazy autumn conditions that allowed Native American Indians to continue hunting. Whatever the origin of the phrase, it was first used in the eastern United States.  The first recorded use of the phrase appears in a letter written by a Frenchman called John de Crevecoeur dated January 17 1778.  In his description of the Mohawk country he writes: Sometimes the rain is followed by an interval of calm and warm which is called the Indian summer. The term was first used in the UK in the early 19th century and went on to gain widespread usage.  But the concept of a warm autumn spell was not new to the UK. Previously, iations of Saint Martin's summer were widely used across Europe to describe warm weather surrounding St Martin's Day on November 11.  Amanda James, 45, spotted the unusual weather formation while her young son was playing in the garden and quickly grabbed her camera to capture a picture. She shared it online through UK Southwest Storm Chasers Ltd who revealed the clouds had been spotted in at ious sites around Cornwall, including this one in Truro. According to the Met Office funnel clouds - or 'tuba' - are extending, spinning fingers of cloud that reach towards the ground or surface of the sea but don't touch it. Amanda said she was watching it form for about 20 minutes.  She added: I was out in the garden with my son playing when I spotted it. I found the funnel cloud fascinating to watch and am keen on photography so loved taking the photos. It was quite amazing to watch. Funnel clouds are often associated with extreme weather conditions such as rain, hail, thunder and lightning. Upon reaching the ground, the cloud would become a tornado, which can produce very strong winds and potentially cause severe damage. A spokesman for the Met Office said: In the UK they often look like thin dangling bits of rope, hanging from the cloud above. But in hotspots such as tornado alley in the USA, funnel clouds can sometimes be thicker and much more intense.

title: woman who fled home wrapped
story: NewsWoman who fled home wrapped in bedsheet after “monster” ex-boyfriend repeatedly stamped on her head slams soft sentenceKirsty Schofield, 38, of Bolton, had to flee to her neighbour's house wearing nothing but a bed sheet following the sustained and vicious attack in JuneShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByEmma CramptonEd McConnell17:06, 2 SEP 2018NewsBruising left by Bobby Stewart "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman left slipping in and out of conciousness after her thug ex repeatedly stamped on her head has branded his two-year prison sentence ridiculous. Victim Kirsty Schofield, 38, had to flee to her neighbour's home wearing just a bed sheet to escape vicious Bobby Stewart, 29. He'd become obsessed by the idea she was cheating on him when he launched the sustained attack in June. Just four days earlier he'd been released from police custody where he'd been on remand for a similar attack. The assault left the mum-of-one fearing for her life and led to her dialling 999 and making what a judge described as one of the most desperate phone calls he had ever heard.  Stewart had arrived at her home after a day of drinking and eventually lost control and attacked Miss Schofield as she cowered underneath the bathroom sink. After a 30-minute stand-off, during which she begged Stewart to call an ambulance, she escaped to the safety of her neighbours, wearing only bed sheets. Last month at Bolton Crown Court Stewart stuck two fingers up at her as he was sentenced via video link. Judge Timothy Clayson jailed Stewart for 15 months for actual bodily harm and nine months to run concurrently for breaching a suspended sentence order and also imposed a restraining order banning him from contacting Miss Schofield.  Miss Schofield, of Bolton, said: I honestly didn't think he was going to stop until he killed me. He looked evil and that's when I saw him for what he was. Before I could always forgive him, but not after that. She says she suffered months of emotional and physical abuse fat the hands of Stewart, which turned her into a nervous wreck and affected her work and isolated her from friends. Stewart would check her phone daily, force her to block friends and family and even called her at work if she didn't respond to his texts immediately. Miss Schofield said: “I actually met Bobby through his sister who I worked with last July and staggeringly she warned me off him. “I didn’t listen though as in my eyes he was wonderful, but it didn’t take long for the abuse to start and after two months he started getting violent. “It’s easy to say now that I’m at the other side I should have left him but I couldn't. I thought he was the love of my life and I wanted to be there for him and fix him.”  The violence continued and Stewart was arrested for assault by beating but Kirsty dropped the charges before the case went to trial. Desperate to believe he had changed, she took him back but Stewart attacked Kirsty the day he was released. Miss Schofield added: “I hoped jail would make him change his ways and when he called me saying he loved me and he was so sorry I believed every single word. I was brainwashed.  “So I naively dropped all charges but I was so so wrong, I should have left him to rot where he deserved to be. “He wanted payback for me getting him locked up and he was obsessed with the idea I’d cheated on him. Which I would never do. He was screaming at me that he knew I had and he wouldn't stop until I admitted it. “He dragged me around my own home and demanded I didn’t go to work the next day as he didn’t want me to leave his sight, he was so paranoid and controlling.” Describing the final attack she said: “He had been drinking and burst into the flat again. He was adamant I had been unfaithful and demanded to look through my phone. “Ridiculously, the last person who had called me was a taxi driver saying he was outside and he even rang the firm convinced I was having an affair with the taxi driver. “His eyes were wild and he just saw red so I ran to the bathroom wrapped in bedsheets and cowered under the sink where he hit and kicked me and stamped on my head. “I was sick and kept going in and out of consciousness and I begged him to call an ambulance but he just sat there and said I deserved it.”

story: NewsMexican city gives green light to SEX in public streets with police 'not bothering you' UNLESS someone complainsCouples in Mexico's second-largest city will be able to have sex in public as part of changes to tackle police corruptionShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByClaire Gilbody-Dickerson15:06, 2 SEP 2018Updated15:09, 2 SEP 2018NewsCouple will be able to have sex in the public eye in Mexico's second-largest city "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A Mexican city is set for whole new levels of hotness as loved-up couples will be able to openly have sex on the streets with impunity.  Under new reforms approved in the western Mexican city of Guadalajara, police officers will still be able to report couple performing sexual acts, but only if a citizen raises a formal complaint.  Having sexual relations or committing acts of exhibitionism of a sexual nature in public places, vacant lots, inside vehicles or in private locations in public view” will only be considered an offence when flagged by a disgruntled citizen, the amendment to the Regulation of Police and Good Government states.   According to Mexican news site El Universal, the new measures approved in August are aimed at tackling police extortion in the city.  The reforms, presented by the Citizen Movement councilor, Guadalupe Morfin Otero, would allow for couples to “exchange their love” without fear of officers threatening them with jail if they don't give them some cash in return.  The act can cause annoyance, but if there is no complaint the police cannot act. He stressed, however, that if the act involves minors or is a violation, the police must certainly intervene because it is a crime.  The councillor went on: Displays of affection in the public highway are free and no police of Guadalajara will be able to bother you if there is no denunciation, he said, according to Publimetro.  It comes after a survey of students from both public and private universities found 90 percent of people had been confronted by police demanding they paid them or face being locked up in Mexico’s jails, known locally as “separados”.

title: music legend sir jimmy shands collection goes on display in dundee
story: Newly-restored rare musical manuscripts collected by the legendary Sir Jimmy Shand are to go on display in Dundee.The books and sheet music were donated to the Wighton Centre at Central Library in 2013 after they were acquired at auction by the Friends of Wighton.Following a lengthy restoration process, which led to some books having to be conserved page by page, the volumes are now ready to be enjoyed by the public.A launch ceremony is being held at the Wighton Centre today at 11am, which will be attended by Sir Jimmy’s son Jimmy Jr and his wife Margaret.Jimmy Jr and his family also contributed additional material to the rare collection of classical Scottish scripts.Members of the Friends of Wighton’s instrumental classes will play a selection of tunes from the collection.Sheena Wellington, of the Friends of Wighton, said Sir Jimmy, pictured right, had been a discerning collector of books and manuscripts, some of which are hundreds of years old.Sheena – who like Sir Jimmy is an inductee of the Scottish Traditional Music Hall of Fame – said: “We’re absolutely thrilled to have them on display and we have some real rarities.“There is a collection of 19th Century books bound into one volume that we believe could be a first edition.”Among some of the other treasures are an 18th Century collection of harpsichord songs and a book of ancient Orkney melodies from 1885.There is also is a volume of ballroom songs from 1870, of which no catalogue record exists in any library in the world – making it unique.Jimmy Jr said his dad – who died in 2000 at the age of 92 – would be “overwhelmed” to know his collection was being shared with the city.“I’m delighted about it all – my father would have been delighted too, that it is now something the public can enjoy,” he said.“We wish the Wighton Centre every success with the collection and hope a lot of folk come to see it.”In total, the collection comprises 23 volumes, some of which will be on public display.The rest can be viewed on request, under the supervision of a librarian.Funding for the conservation was provided through fundraising efforts and a grant from the Heritage Lottery Fund. The careful work was carried out by hand, by local professional book expert Emma Fraser.Sheena said that Emma, who runs The Book and Paper Studio on Union Street, had done a “beautiful job”.While the legendary accordion player is often linked with Auchtermuchty, Sir Jimmy spent many years in Dundee and lived in Lochee for 20 years.The City of Discovery had a unique part to play in his story.He was already an accomplished player of the melodeon – similar to an accordion – when he discovered the instrument that would make him famous.Sheena said: “He walked by Forbes’s music shop on the Nethergate and saw an accordion in the window.“I believe a pal said to him to go in and have a wee go.“He started to play and the owner realised he was a bit special and gave him a job selling accordions.“The rest, as they say, is history.”

title: Changes in pipeline for Victorian Market
story: A RARE opportunity could be on the cards for creative use of a store in a prime Inverness location.Highland councillors will decide today whether the vacant outlet within the city' Victorian Market can be used for myriad purposes.It comes after it was announced earlier this week that the council has been meeting with market figureheads about rebranding and renaming the premises, which are owned by the Inverness Common Good Fund.The catalyst for the move involving the vacant unit was a talented Highland arts student' recent use of the site for an exhibition &ndash Becoming Bellany &ndash in tribute to the late acclaimed Scottish artist John Bellany.It generated considerable interest among shoppers and market retailers in Unit 15 which has been vacant for a couple of years, failing to reap an approximate market rent of &pound13,000 per year.Market manager Jo Murray said: &ldquoIt' one of our largest units and taking it on full time would be quite a commitment but I could see the value of using the space as a flexible space for pop-up shops, exhibitions, charity work or workshops.&ldquoWe&rsquove also picked up on the need for a meeting space, with a number of organisations saying they&rsquod welcome such a space for events.&ldquoIt would be great to have somebody using it. It changes the dynamic in the market hall. It' a great unit with fantastic windows and great visibility.The idea is to charge &pound20 per hour for use of the premises.If the initiative is approved by the council' city committee, Mrs Murray promised the unit would be redecorated before it is let.Meanwhile, the market could be renamed Old Town Arcade Inverness in a major rebranding exercise.The proposal has emerged after talks between interested parties and council, which has employed consultant Tristram Woolston Design of Cannich to look at the marketing of the landmark, which has often been a focal point for city visitors from home and abroad.Mrs Murray said further talks will be held before it goes to Highland councillors for consideration.&ldquoThe consultant has identified problems with the existing name, in that the building and its environment doesn&rsquot strongly present Victorian qualities and it' not a &lsquomarket&rsquo as such, but has permanent enclosed retail units rather than changeable stalls, she said.&ldquoThe vision for this historic building after refurbishment is to provide a high-quality destination with a mix of unique Highland brands and products, a place to eat and drink, and a venue for events and entertainment.&ldquoOther similar destinations in the UK and abroad call themselves arcades and hence the proposed new name is Old Town Arcade Inverness.Those involved will discuss the new image for the facility in September.Inverness economist Tony Mackay said it might be better to focus on other matters.&ldquoTo be honest I&rsquom not sure what sort of impact changing the name will have, he said.&ldquoThere needs to be improvements at the market, there are a few empty premises in the centre. It' gone downhill due to lack of investments and the decline in people shopping in the city centre.&ldquoWe need to move away from the traditional shopping idea, more social activities and more attractions are what is needed. The shops at the Victorian Market shut at 5pm. Staying open later and having maybe street entertainers there in the evening could attract more people.Sunday 2 Sep 2018 10:36 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Dont miss chance to nominate a hero
story: TIME is running out to nominate someone you know to be one of this year's Highland Heroes.The awards, organised by SPP Media and now in their second year, celebrate people in the Highlands who make a real difference to our communities, healthcare, education, safety and wellbeing.Readers are being invited to nominate people in any of the 12 categories: primary pupil, secondary pupil, primary teacher, secondary teacher, carer, fundraiser, volunteer, community champion, brave child, health professional, emergency services or armed forces hero and public servant.The deadline for nominations is midnight tomorrow.SPP Media's editorial director David Bourn said: "This is a last call for you to tell us about the real heroes who go above and beyond to make your community, workplace or school a special place."Highland Heroes wants to celebrate the contribution people in our area make to the lives of others by giving them the recognition they deserve."So if you know a Highland Hero, now is the time to share their story."To nominate somebody for the awards, visit www.surveymonkey/r/HighlandHeroes2018 or email heroes@spp-group with your name, address, email and phone number, along with the person you are nominating, up to 200 words to explain why, and their contact details.After the deadline closes, a judging panel will draw up a shortlist in each category before readers are given the opportunity to vote for their favourites in a special supplement we will publish in September.The winners of each category, along with an overall hero, will be announced at a ceremony at the Kingsmills Hotel in Inverness on Thursday, November 8.The awards are sponsored by Inverness Airport.* Click here to read more about Highland Heroes.Sunday 2 Sep 2018 10:36 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Exhibition plans revealed after dinosaur find
story: &nbsp&nbspIt comes amid excitement at the recent discovery of dinosaur footprints near the city &ndash the first time they have been discovered on the Scottish mainland.Inverness museum, which is bidding for &pound15,500 from the Inverness Common Good Fund to stage the exhibition, says British Dinosaurs will have the &ldquowow factor and believes it would benefit the city centre.In its application for funding, the museum stated: &ldquoThere is huge public demand for a dinosaur exhibition but to date we have not been able to fulfil this demand because our venue is too small and the high costs involved are unaffordable.&ldquoHowever, we have managed to source an exhibition which will be tailored for Inverness Museum and Art Gallery which will have the wow factor.The exhibition, set to take place between November and late January, will contain casts of dinosaur skeletons including a plesiosaur, the type suggested to be the Loch Ness Monster.Objects from Perth Museum and the Dinosaur Museum in Skye will also be on show plus interactive and holographic displays.Exhibitions officer Cathy Shankland said if it goes ahead, it would involve extending the usually reduced winter hours.&ldquoEveryone loves dinosaurs, she said.&ldquoThe fact there has been the discovery of footprints on the city' doorstep makes it even more exciting.Alison Parfitt, collections engagement curator, said High Life Highland services had run a summer activity programme with a dinosaur focus while a creative challenge, the Design-a-Saurus, is being developed with a strong science, technology, engineering and maths focus.Dr Neil Clark, curator of palaeontology at the Hunterian Museum in Glasgow, announced last week he had found dinosaur footprints, thought to be 170 million years old, at a coastal site near Inverness.- The latest applications to the Inverness Common Good Fund will be presented to the city committee on Thursday.Sunday 2 Sep 2018 10:36 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Inverness legends and history comes to life through new plaques and digital app
story: &nbsp&nbspThe artwork on the plaques acts as a trigger for an app which uses augmented reality to bring a story to life using technology.The eighth and final plaque was installed on the Falcon Square statue. The artwork shows a magical garden with a unicorn and falcon.The Mercat Cross which was unveiled in 2003 in Falcon Square is a sandstone pillar, 37ft high adorned with a rearing unicorn and a falcon shown spiralling down the column in the four successive stages of its attacking manoeuvre.A link in the app takes you to more information about the unicorn and the stories of the other legends in Inverness.The augmented reality trail includes plaques at the Victorian Market, Inverness Castle, Ness Walk and Eden Court.The HighlandAR Legends app is part of a Highland Council project under the City-Region Deal.The council' communication and resilience manager Ruth Cleland said: &ldquoThe app will be good for the area. It is something that is unique to Inverness and it will give tourists something different to do when they visit the city.&ldquoNot only is it educational but it will hopefully benefit local businesses as well.The Inverness Common Good Fund provided funding for the artworks which were designed by local artists and the council' graphic designer Kirsty Foster. Darroch McNaught of Deuxality created the HighlandAR app and augmented reality experiences.&ldquoCreating the app has been amazing and everyone seems so excited about it, he said.&ldquoInverness is the first city in the UK to use augmented reality like this and I think it will have a huge impact on tourism.The full launch of the HighlandAR-Legends trail is set to take place this autumn.HighlandAR-Legends is now free to download from Google Play and the Apple App Store.Sunday 2 Sep 2018 10:36 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: New funding boost for college autism project
story: &nbsp&nbspCantraybridge College, which caters for people with additional needs, received &pound239,028 for its Autistic Enterprisers initiative from the Social Economy Growth Fund.The award will be used to train 84 people in how to identify business ideas, and will help them set up their own supported enterprises.The college' chief executive Jenny Liddell said: &ldquoAutistic Enterprisers is no ordinary business education programme.&ldquoIt combines enterprise education with personal support to assist individuals in overcoming both professional and personal barriers to becoming self-employed.&ldquoIt also offers options for a range of continuing support once a new business is launched.The programme is predicted to create 18 new businesses by 2020.Autistic Enterprisers is open to any adult on the autistic spectrum who lives in the Highland area.As part of the programme, Cantraybridge is currently in the process of recruiting an enterprise trainer and autism counsellor, who will travel throughout the region to offer individual support.The Scottish Government' communities secretary Aileen Campbell said: &ldquoThe Social Economy Growth Fund enables organisations to design and deliver community-led solutions to overcome poverty, disadvantage and inequalities &ndash which is a key principle of our Fairer Scotland Action Plan.&ldquoWe are encouraging councils and third sector partners to develop local strategies that advance the social enterprise sector in every part of Scotland.Research findings from the programme will be presented to the Scottish Government, and similar projects could be opened nationally.Sunday 2 Sep 2018 10:36 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: New golf course clubhouse takes shape as part of Inverness West Link
story: &nbsp&nbspEight of the holes at Torvean Golf Club are being relocated and a new clubhouse is being built so that the current site can be used for the next phase of the West Link project.Councillors and Highland Council staff were taken on a tour of the development last week and hailed the impact of the new, improved facilities.Inverness South councillor Duncan Macpherson was among those who attended the visit and believes the new facilities can have the same positive effect on the whole community as Highland Rugby Club' Canal Park.&ldquoMore and more people are using the excellent facilities at the rugby club and we are hoping that the new facilities at Torvean will have the same effect, he said.&ldquoA new modern clubhouse being built will improve the facilities for everyone.&ldquoIt' going to be a totally upgraded golf course with some wonderful features.&ldquoThe course is going to be hugely enhanced, and hopefully that will lead to an increase in members and participation as we have seen since the new facilities were built at the rugby club.Cllr Macpherson also believes there is potential for the area to be enhanced for non-golfers.&ldquoThere' also a lot of potential for it to become a new city park, he added.&ldquoThe natural serenity of the area is magnificent.&ldquoFurther down the line there is a lot of potential for other things to go in there as well.Once the revamped golf course is playable, work will begin on the next stage of the West Link.The councillors&rsquo visit was held in advance of a public consultation on the next stage of the plans, and Cllr Macpherson says the success of the first stage shows that the project has made a difference.&ldquoWe have already seen the positive impact the first phase of the new West Link has had on the city, he said.&ldquoThat' something which has taken pressure off roads in the city centre.&ldquoNow with the next phase, we will have two swing bridges over the canal.&ldquoThat will ease a lot of frustration for drivers because one of them will always be open.The public consultation into the second stage of the West Link will be held at Canal Park on September 5.Cllr Macpherson urged local residents to attend the event and &ldquotake their chance to make their voice heard.Meanwhile, Highland Council has submitted a planning application to build 34 houses and flats close to the golf course on land south of Golf View Terrace.Permission was granted in principle in December 2016.Sunday 2 Sep 2018 10:36 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Vandalised cars issue to be discussed at meeting
story: VANDALS have targeted several cars in an Inverness neighbourhood causing damage to wing mirrors.Community leaders in South Kessock will raise the issue at their next monthly meeting and are also urging local residents to report any incidents to the police immediately.Alex Platt, chairman of the South Kessock Resident Association, said he was aware of three incidents in the Carnac Crescent and Rosehaugh Road areas over the last two weekends.&ldquoIt is not a regular occurrence but it is annoying to see it happen, he said.&ldquoI think it is youngsters although I don&rsquot have proof.&ldquoThey are not showing respect for people' property.&ldquoThey don&rsquot realise that these things cost money to repair &ndash money that people don&rsquot have, or that car insurance goes up.&ldquoIn general, this is a good area to live but this sort of thing happens all over.Mr Platt said he had emailed the community police officer about the issue and it would be discussed at the association' next meeting to be held on September 18.&ldquoMy advice to people is to call the police straight away if they see this sort of activity, he said.&ldquoThere are a lot of positive things going on in the area and this sort of thing will not be tolerated.Sunday 2 Sep 2018 10:36 PM&nbsp&nbsp
